Award.AwardTitle: Intensification and impact of wave-breaking in river plumes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fronts form barriers that limit the exchange of nutrients and organisms between different water masses in the ocean. This study will investigate if wave breaking can intensify mixing at fronts between an expanding fresh water river plume and the ambient salt water offshore. The work will also contribute to the general understanding of wave-breaking and near-surface turbulence, which influence a myriad processes in the ocean. The project will support one graduate student and several outreach efforts which include maintaining a research blog and producing a video segment which will be hosted by the Applied Physics Laboratory/University of Washington website.

This project will use a novel wave-turbulence measurement platform to quantify the transformation of wave energy as it passes through a river plume front and interior, as well as the impact of wave-breaking turbulence on the dynamics and mixing of the plume. The overarching hypothesis is that plume velocity gradients can intensify wave breaking, converting wave energy to turbulence, and significantly increasing plume mixing in systems where the wave scales match the vertical plume scale. The plan is to test this hypothesis by pursuing the following three specific objectives using new and existing field data: 1) quantify the loss of wave energy via breaking at fronts and within river plumes, 2) quantify the generation of near-surface turbulence during wave breaking and the vertical structure of this turbulence, and 3) assess the impact of wave breaking turbulence on mixing in river plumes. Measurements of waves, near-surface turbulence, and buoyancy flux will be done in the moderate-sized Fraser River plume (British Columbia, Canada) and the smaller-sized Elwha River plume (Washington, USA) under a range of wave conditions. Results from these measurements will be compared with existing wave and turbulence data from the much larger Columbia River plume to determine how wave-turbulence dynamics are influenced by frontal strength in different systems. The impact of this process on mixing will be assessed using drifter-based salt budgets as well as analysis of more than a decade of ferry transect data through the Fraser River plume

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rivers transport sediment, nutrients, and pollutants from the terrestrial to the marine environment, and the fate of this material is important for coastal morphology, ecosystem function, and public health. This research project investigated the processes by which surface waves influence the fate of river discharge in the coastal ocean. We focus specifically on processes that influence the rate that river water mixes with coastal ocean water, since that determines the concentrations of river-borne matter, and the transport pathways of river water. The project included two major field campaigns, which examined wave effects on large and small river outflows, respectively.

 

Based on measurements from the Fraser River plume near Vancouver, Canada, we showed that wind and waves strongly influenced the lateral spreading rate of the plume. Winds from the north, which opposed the northward tendency of the plume, caused the plume to flow into the receiving waters as a narrower, deeper and faster plume, relative to low wind conditions when the plume spread widely to the north. Since the rate that the plume mixes with ambient coastal water depends on the spreading rate, this tendency was a primary control on the location and intensity of plume mixing. We found that mixing due to wave breaking turbulence was secondary in the Fraser River plume.

 

Small river outflows that directly enter the surf zone, where waves break near the shore, are a common feature of the world's coastlines. Breaking waves release their energy and momentum in the surf zone, causing it to be energetic and turbulent, yet retentive, as surf zone cross-shore exchange is small on average. Thus, river water and river-borne material may become trapped in the surf zone. Trapped fresh river water is subject to energetic alongshore circulation and turbulence, and may be transported away from the river mouth, undergoing wave-driven mixing.


We used observations from the Quinault River (see Figure), which flows into an energetic surf zone on Quinault Indian Nation land north of Grays Harbor, WA, to investigate the interaction between river and wave forcing in the surf zone. By synthesizing data from moorings, drifters, and Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) video, we developed a conceptual model of this interaction based on river forcing, wave forcing, and the bathymetry near the river mouth. Our conceptual model predicts when the surf zone traps the outflowing river water and when the river water escapes to the coastal ocean.

 

We find that river water is trapped most of the time, because the wave forcing overwhelms the river forcing. River water escapes the surf zone under two scenarios; at low tide when the river velocity is highest during low tide, and when wave forcing is low, river forcing dominates over wave forcing and river water escapes the surf zone. Second, at high tide during low wave forcing, bathymetric effects can allow the river water to bypass wave forcing. In this case minimal wave breaking occurs in the channel and river water escapes onto the shelf. Based on the discharge, wave, and tidal conditions, we used the conceptual model to predict the fate of water from the Quinault River over a year, showing that approximately 70% of the annual river discharge is initially trapped in the surf zone upon exiting the river mouth. The trapped river water flows along the shoreline in the surf zone until it is eventually mixed or transported into the ambient coastal waters by lateral mixing, rip currents or other cross-shelf transport mechanisms.

We also investigated the rate that Quinault River water mixes with ocean water to understand what sets the salinity of the surf zone, and the dilution of river-borne matter. Mixing requires that energetic turbulence is co-located with a freshwater-salt water gradient. We observed that wave breaking always provided sufficient turbulence in the surf zone and that mixing was limited by the salt water fraction in the surf zone. When river discharge was high, the surf zone was filled with freshwater and there was very little mixing. When river discharge was low, as occurred at high tide, salt water intruded into the surf zone and resulted in strong vertical stratification. Under these conditions the colocation of wave-breaking turbulence and the salinity gradient resulted in the highest mixing.

 

This project supported the training of one PhD student and one undergraduate student. The project team also interacted with the Quinault Indian Nation, who participated as advisors and guides for the duration of our experiments on the Quinault River. Our results were disseminated in follow-up meetings with the Quinault Division of Natural Resources, as well as in seven conference presentations and one submitted and three published journal articles. In addition, in each year we have used a estuary demo experiment to teach K-5 students about the science of the river-ocean system as part of UW Discover Days.
